{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3377719,"name":"","username":"Nimble","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-01T02:54:34.021Z","cooked":"

Was looking into accessing networktables using node.js for a project.

Would it be possible to read data from tables using a websocket? On local simulation, I was able to connect to addresses such as ws://127.0.0.1:5810/nt/Shuffleboard using insomnia, but it received no data. Just wondering if this is possible or if there are any examples of this out there.

Yes it’s designed to be compatible with standard web technologies. It won’t just give you a blast of data, you need to ask for what you want. See the specification here: allwpilib/ntcore/doc/networktables4.adoc at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

There are several TypeScript and JavaScript implementations that exist already. In addition to the one Justin mentioned, there’s also this one: Add NT4 Javascript by gerth2 · Pull Request #1 · wpilibsuite/NetworkTablesClients · GitHub

The NT4 code that FWC uses lives here: frc-web-components/packages/fwc/src/source-providers/nt4/NT4.ts at master · frc-web-components/frc-web-components (github.com)

It’s based off of the code from the PR Peter linked to in his comment: Add NT4 Javascript by gerth2 · Pull Request #1 · wpilibsuite/NetworkTablesClients · GitHub

Mine has a few additions such as being able to subscribe to multiple client topics using the .subscribeAll method. For the FWC dashboard I do client.subscribeAll(["/"], true) to subscribe to all topics. You can copy this code in your own project if you’d like to use it or install the @frc-web-components/fwc package and import it like this:

import { Nt4Client } from "@frc-web-components/fwc/source-providers";

For most use cases I would say ntcore-ts-client is probably the best option though. It has some limitations like only being able to subscribe to individual topics, but it seems like the most up-to-date NT4 implementation and also has documentation. It also has been updated to support NT4 4.1 which mine currently does not. I can’t comment on how well it performs at competitions since I’ve never used it, but I don’t see any issues open related to that so it’s probably fine.
